model_input:
Your task is to choose a more helpful MEMORY based on the below criterion.

CRITERION:
Helpfulness - The MEMORY should contain sufficient quantity of useful information, enabling the Speaker A to respond in an appropriate context to the last utterance of the CURRENT DIALOGUE CONTEXT. PREVIOUS DIALOGUE SUMMARY is a summary of the previous dialog, and If the MEMORY contains information that conflicts with the PREVIOUS DIALOGUE SUMMARY, it is not helpful in that context.

The output format should be as follows:
Explanation: (a brief explanation)
Choice: (answer with "1", "2", or "tie")

Now choose the MEMORY that has better Helpfulness.

PREVIOUS DIALOGUE SUMMARY:
Speaker A fosters dogs till they find a forever home.
Speaker B works as a zoo keeper and enjoys it.
Speaker A works in software solutions for tech companies and finds it less exciting than being a zoo keeper.
Speaker A's job involves troubleshooting, including the common phrase "did you try turning it on and off again?".
Speaker B's brother owns a grocery store and thinks people can be dumb there.
Speaker A is interested in animals, specifically raccoons and bearded dragons.
Speaker B works at a Raccoon Cafe and takes care of Bandicoot, a raccoon.
Bandicoot is 3 years old, while Bob the bearded dragon is 7 months old.
Bandicoot was a rescue and has been at the Raccoon Cafe since he was a baby.
Speaker A has not interacted closely with raccoons but admires them.
Speaker B considers raccoons intelligent and funny.
Raccoons are known for being able to escape despite efforts to secure trash containers.
Speaker B has only had Bob the bearded dragon for about a month.
Speaker A visited a pet store and saw a bearded dragon for the first time.
Speaker B owns a raccoon named Bandicoot and a bearded dragon named Bob.
Speaker A fosters dogs and is concerned about adding a bearded dragon to their household.
Speaker B's raccoon Bandicoot is not bothered by the bearded dragon Bob.
Speaker A is worried about the raccoon potentially eating the bearded dragon.
Speaker A hears raccoons and cats fighting in their neighborhood.
Speaker B has been taking care of the raccoon for over a month and is interested in training it.
Speaker B believes raccoons can make good pets if cared for properly.
Speaker B mentioned that raccoons cannot legally be sold as pets, but can be rescued and cared for before being released back into the wild.
Speaker A fosters dogs and is used to them coming and going.
Speaker A is allergic to cats, so they do not foster them.
Speaker B has a dog named Bandicoot and is willing to bring him over for extra company.
Speaker A is dealing with a raccoon problem and plans to buy aluminum sheeting to cover up holes.
Speaker A does not have bears around their area.
Speaker B's garbage has a lock to prevent animals from getting into it, especially during windy weather.

CURRENT DIALOGUE CONTEXT:
Speaker A: I was able to get the aluminum sheeting for my garbage. I'm going to install it today and I'll let you know how my raccoon problem goes. 
Speaker B: I hope it goes well for you. How come you don't just leave small bowls of food out and befriend the raccoons? It would solve your problem a lot faster, especially because raccoon's are so smart. Bandicoot knows how to open and unlock so many things, it's makes it difficult to keep him out of trouble. Which is why I take him to work with me.
Speaker A: Ohhh.  That would be bad. I really do not want more raccoons or other animals coming around.  I like them OK, but I do not want to have some diseased ones get close to the house. 
Speaker B: Understandable. Have you ever tried contacting animal control? That's how I got Bandicoot. I was working that day and animal control came by explaining about needing fosters for raccoons. I thought it was weird, so I did it and began to work at the small raccoon cafe that is part of the zoo. I love it. 
Speaker A: That is a good idea.  Maybe they could help move them to a safer area.  I have a lot of traffic around and they could get hit if they are coming to my place all the time.  Have you been able to teach your raccoon any tricks?
Speaker B: The only trick I was able to teach him, that I deeply regret, was how locks worked. I thought it was cool at first, you know, to see a raccoon unlock a door. And now, I regret it so much. I've had to change the layout of my apartment and put deadbolts on my doors so that Bandicoot can't get out. And, he is sneaky about it. One time, he unlocked the pantry and was eating some cookies! It's like having a toddler that never grows up.
Speaker A: That is bad I guess.  Do you keep all of your chemicals, poisons, and medications up and locked?  I would hate to think what might happen if Bandicoot got into any of that.  Hey, when you drive do you lock him up in a cage or let him wander around in the car?  That could be dangerous for you driving and he freaks out.
Speaker B: All the chemicals and poisons are in a gated lock in the basement. The lock requires a specific key, which I have hidden in my drawers. For medication, I have a small box that I also keep locked up, but it's a combination lock, so Bandicoot isn't able to get into it. For driving, I bought a harness that keeps him strapped in the back seat, he can move a bit, but mostly sturdy. I put blankets down and his favorite toys so that he stays calm. Sometimes, I'll pass small snacks to keep him occupied. I also take the side streets to work so that it's not too much for him. What about you? When you foster dogs, do you put them in a cage when you drive?
Speaker A: I do keep the dogs secured. You never knwo how they are going to react.  Most of them I only have for a few days, so I really do not get a chance to see how they will act in all situations.  
Speaker B: Oh, does that make you want to adopt a dog? I know you said it makes you sad to see them come and go, so why not adopt one? 

MEMORY 1:
Speaker A is interested in animals, specifically raccoons and bearded dragons. Speaker B believes raccoons can make good pets if cared for properly. Speaker B's garbage has a lock to prevent animals from getting into it, especially during windy weather. 
Speaker A works in software solutions for tech companies and finds it less exciting than being a zoo keeper. Speaker B works at a Raccoon Cafe and takes care of Bandicoot, a raccoon. Speaker B has been taking care of the raccoon for over a month and is interested in training it. Speaker A is dealing with a raccoon problem and plans to buy aluminum sheeting to cover up holes.

User Description: Speaker B is a zookeeper who works at a Raccoon Cafe. They have a bearded dragon named Bob and a raccoon named Bandicoot, whom they have had since Bandicoot was a baby. Speaker B is experienced in taking care of Bandicoot and Bob, ensuring they are fed correctly with insects and dog kibble. Speaker B's brother owns a grocery store.

Relationship Description: Speaker A fosters dogs and interacts with Speaker B regarding their pets. Speaker A is interested in learning about raccoons and bearded dragons, showing concern for the well-being of foster dogs in the presence of reptiles. The dialogue between Speaker A and Speaker B reflects a friendly and curious relationship.

Event Description: Speaker B shared experiences of wild raccoons trying to steal food from working raccoons and discussed the intelligence and behavior of raccoons with Speaker A. Speaker B expressed interest in researching whether raccoons can be trained and shared insights on caring for raccoons as pets. Speaker A asked questions about the behavior and care of raccoons, showing interest in wildlife laws and proper pet care.

YOUR OUTPUT:
prediction:
